stream_context.summary: Kaze finishes the last Yoshi-coin objective in the Western/desert course by coding a new ‘bandit’ enemy, debugs trains and particles, and declares the level essentially content-complete pending art, music and animation polish.

development_findings.summary: Implemented a new “bandit” NPC that approaches Mario only when the player looks away, steals coins out of Mario’s inventory, then flees along a preset path and drops a Yoshi-coin.
development_findings.quote: He steals your coins and if you catch him… he should say something like, “Oh, I wasn’t doing anything,” run off and spawn a Yoshi coin.

development_findings.summary: If the player has zero coins, the bandit shows alternate dialogue and immediately gifts a Yoshi-coin out of pity (hidden easter-egg).
development_findings.quote: If you have no coins here, he should say something like, “Wow, you’re broke… here’s a Yoshi coin for you.”

development_findings.summary: Yoshi-coins fully replace 100-coin stars; collecting five in a stage grants a star, inspired by Sunshine’s 100-coin Shines but without the ‘single run’ constraint.
development_findings.quote: I think people would hate [100-coin stars] less if you didn’t have to get them in one go… that’s how I want the Yoshi coins to work.

development_findings.summary: Trains are spline-driven objects that now loop the map continuously; a spawn-height bug made them fall through the stage and was fixed by adjusting their initial position and path data.
development_findings.quote: Why are the trains just on the floor? … the spline must be wrong. Moving it inside the warp fixed it.

development_findings.summary: Particle systems weren’t despawning on area transitions; Kaze added a global ‘lock graphics’ check and logged a todo for proper clean-up.
development_findings.quote: Particles do not despawn when you area-transition… very important—remind me to fix that.

development_findings.summary: Pokey enemy optimised from ~31 raycasts per frame to one, greatly reducing CPU load.
development_findings.quote: Turns out it’s more like 31… I reduced it to one; I think that’s a little more reasonable.

development_findings.summary: The level now contains 410 text boxes—already ~3× the original SM64—with multilingual cowboy-style dialogue generated via ChatGPT.
development_findings.quote: ChatGPT is honestly my main use at the moment—as a cowboy-translation machine.

development_findings.summary: Compiler note about using the FP register across threads spammed every build; solved by recasting to f32 and adding compile flags after futile Stack Overflow queries.
development_findings.quote: Thanks all of you… the issue has been resolved by soft skills.

development_findings.summary: Decision reaffirmed: the hack intentionally targets emulator/modern hardware, not real N64, enabling multi-threading, large memory pools and tech like custom microcode.
development_findings.quote: You will never get this running on real hardware… usually at the very beginning people decide whether they want to and most say no.

development_findings.summary: Plans for end-of-project polish include per-level ambience passes (music off), wood footstep SFX, climbable surface flags and a ‘champion’s route’ for 100 %.

context_findings.summary: Frustration with Stack Overflow culture and AI ‘non-solutions’ reveals Kaze’s DIY ethos and impatience for bureaucracy.
context_findings.quote: If you don’t know how to get rid of the warning, shut up.

context_findings.summary: Financial hurdles: Patreon finally fixed after 1.5 years; PayPal funds still frozen; suggests Ko-fi to others.
context_findings.quote: Any money you send me on PayPal, I can’t use it—it’s all just frozen in time.

context_findings.summary: Long-term career thinking: future projects may shift to Unreal for better monetisation; an Ocarina of Time mega-hack is a passion wish but ‘not lucrative’.
context_findings.quote: I would like to make another Ocarina of Time hack… but most likely it will be my own game made in Unreal Engine just ’cause I have to think about the financial aspects.

context_findings.summary: Acknowledges legal barrier to selling N64 carts and anticipates bootleg repros; researching copy-protection via custom IPL.
context_findings.quote: Too bad I can’t sell N64 games—if only the law wasn’t there to meddle with my affairs… we want some copy protection against bootleg carts.

biobak.summary: Needs to correct vertex colours and other small art issues in the Western level; Kaze notes several spots for cleanup.
biobak.quote: Biobak, if you look at this level you will see a few issues… don’t worry about it, I’ll fix those at the end.

badub.summary: Composing the ‘Western duel’ track, intended to resemble cave music without HMC reverb.
badub.quote: Badub is also currently making a song for the Western duel scene… it’s gonna be very fun.

zeina.summary: Creating final character animations and signage for the level; Kaze cannot declare the stage complete until her work is in.
zeina.quote: All that will be missing is some animations that Zeina’s currently working on and the signs.

key_stories.title: The Bandit Coin Thief
key_stories.summary: Kaze conceptualises and programs a bandit who steals Mario’s coins when unobserved, then refined behaviour to include pity dialogue, tripping animation, coin drop and escape path.
key_stories.challenge: Add a memorable mechanic for the final Yoshi-coin.
key_stories.process: Iterated on lerp code, spawn flags, path-following, coin visibility, and alternate dialogue; adjusted physics and added trip animation trigger.
key_stories.outcome: Feature finished; only needs Zeina’s animation polish. It finalises Yoshi-coin placement for the level.
key_stories.key_quote: If you have no coins here, he should say, “Wow, you’re broke… here’s a Yoshi coin for you.”

key_stories.title: Stack Overflow vs. The FP Register
key_stories.summary: Compiler ‘note’ about floating-point registers flooded Kaze’s build logs. Stack Overflow demanded a minimal repro he considered impossible, leading to frustration.
key_stories.challenge: Eliminate hundreds of GCC notes about using fp registers across threads.
key_stories.process: Posted on Stack Overflow, argued about minimal examples, experimented with pragmas and casting.
key_stories.outcome: Solved locally by recasting to f32 and extra flags; credited ‘soft skills’ and vowed to ignore Stack Overflow.
key_stories.key_quote: How do you want me to write you a code that starts two threads on an N64? That’s unreasonable.

key_stories.title: Trains Off the Rails
key_stories.summary: New spline-based train objects spawned correctly but immediately fell through the map.
key_stories.challenge: Train spawns ignored path elevation and snapped to ground.
key_stories.process: Inspected splines, adjusted spawn height (52→48), verified in-game, and fixed floor-snap logic.
key_stories.outcome: Trains now loop the course smoothly, enabling player rides between stations.
key_stories.key_quote: Why are the trains just on the floor?… Moving it inside the warp fixed it.

key_stories.title: Pokey Performance Fix
key_stories.summary: Original Pokey logic used an excessive 31 raycasts per frame, harming performance.
key_stories.challenge: High CPU cost of multiple raycasts per enemy segment and shadow.
key_stories.process: Audited code, reduced to a single raycast, kept functionality.
key_stories.outcome: Significant optimisation for desert level; example of ongoing engine refactor.
key_stories.key_quote: You guys guessed such high numbers—turns out it’s more like 31. I reduced it to one.
